To plant basil outside, wait until the soil has warmed to at least 10°C -preferably around 21°C for best growth.
Plant in early spring in well cultivated soil. The soil should be well drained, deep, fertile and well supplied with organic matter.
Sow from fall to early spring in average soil. Keep evenly moist. Container friendly. One plant per 12 inch container.
Cantaloupes do best in well-draining soil that is a mix between loamy and sandy. Plant in a spot that gets full sun.
For best flavour, harvest when the root is no more than 2" in diameter. Rich loose soil is best with uniform moisture. Onions and carrots are good companions.
Start the seeds indoors 6 to 8 weeks before the last frost date in your area. Sow the seeds half an inch deep in a pot filled with moist potting mix.
Sow outside in full sun location after danger of frost. Keep evenly moist. Sow from fall (cover or put in greenhouse) to early spring.
Sow outside after danger of frost in early spring. Container friendly - 3 plants for each 12" pot.

Sow under cover (protected) from Mid spring, 3 or 4 seeds 1 inch deep in a 3 inch pot in good compost, and thin later to the best one or two plants per clump. Transplant no later than 3 weeks after seeding as cucumbers have a tap root that can be easily damaged.

Fig trees are dormant and look dead until late spring - early May when new buds arrive. You can check the tree is alive by pressing your nail into the bark of a branch. If the flesh underneath is green, the tree is alive.
https://gardenmadesimple.com/growing-store-bought-garlic
Sweet and seedless. this self pollinating variety produces sweet, medium sized grapes that turn yellow when ripe and can withstand cold winter temperatures.
Kale likes well-drained, fertile soil high in organic matter. This plant prefers plentiful, consistent moisture.
Actinidia Kiwi will grow in a variety of soils in sun or shade and is relatively fool proof.
Sow indoors 8–10 weeks before last anticipated spring frost. Keep moist. Container friendly - 3 plants for each 12" pot.
Beets are a good companion for lettuce.

Lovage is an easy-to-grow, robust and hardy relative of celery and parsley. You can grow it from seed or buy young plants. It’s happy in most soil conditions, needs little maintenance and suffers few problems. Lovage plants are perennial, dying down in late autumn then re-sprouting from the base every spring.

The plant is extremely vigorous and mounds up to 16 inches in height. Blooms come in a variety of colors including yellow, red, orange, mahogany, and rose. This is a bush habit, non-trailing type that holds its blooms well above the attractive foliage. Blossoms are a spicy addition to a salad.
Carrots and Swiss Chard are good companions to onions. Try growing onions with mint to confuse and deter onion fly.
Sow outside in full sun location after danger of frost. Keep evenly moist. Sow from fall (cover or put in greenhouse) to early spring. Container friendly - 3 plants for each 12" pot.
Parsnips prefer a sunny spot with well-drained, deep, loose and composted soil. Avoid planting them in areas where water collects, as this can lead to root rot.
McKenzie Pea - container variety. Planted around 10 May. Sprouted in a few days under the cold frame. Place in a container.

Two days before planting, cut large potatoes into pieces ensuring each piece contains at least one eye. Allow the cut area to cure to prevent the potato from rotting in the ground. Smaller potatoes with one or more eyes can be planted whole.
Garden radishes are usually ready for harvest three to five weeks after planting. You can pull them any time they reach a usable size.

Rhubarb needs an open, sunny or partially shaded site, and rich, moist soil. It will grow well in a sunny, open site, on a wide range of soils, as long as it has been well-prepared with plenty of manure or compost.
Choose a sunny spot with well-drained soil. Spinach prefers full sun, but it can tolerate partial shade. The soil should be well-drained, moist and fertile.

Sow seeds 1" deep. Sow 3 seeds in each spot where you want a plant to grow, and thin to the strongest plant. Space summer squash 18 to 24" apart in rows 3 to 4 feet apart. Give winter squash and pumpkins even more room with a minimum of 3 to 4 feet apart in rows 4 to 6 feet apart.

Winter Squash: Fruit is ripe if your thumbnail doesn’t mark the skin and the stem is dry and brown. Cut the stem about 4cm (2″) from the fruit. Squash survive a light frost, but store better if harvested before frost.
Harvest outer leaves all season. Onions are good companions.
Mild flavored leaves can be used in teas and any recipe calling for thyme. Soft lilac flowers are nice in fresh bouquets.
Tomatoes need well-drained soil that is rich in organic matter. Amend the soil with compost or manure before planting. Tomatoes need regular watering, especially during dry weather.

Looking good through all seasons and growing in any aspect, It is a vigorous grower, yet not overly invasive. It is tough, fully hardy and evergreen with pretty blue flowers produced from Spring through to Autumn, once established it will need next to no attention.

Zucchini are summer squash. Pick them young! Zucchini vines are large and require plenty of growing room, but for those who have room, zucchini is cost-effective, because one plant can produce between 3 and 9 pounds of fruit.
See more or less information about a plant.
